sen.j: 今井町（いまいちょう）は、奈良県橿原市にある町。
sen.e: Imai town is a town located in Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.
Imai town is a town located in Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.
Imai Town is a town located in Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 江戸時代の町並みが残ることで知られる。
sen.e: It is known for still having townscape of the Edo period.
It is known for still having the appearance of the Edo period.
It is known for still having the appearance of the Edo period.

sen.j: 古くは興福寺の荘園で、中世の環濠集落を母体として発展した町である。
sen.e: Being a private estate of the Kofuku-ji Temple in olden times, the town developed from a medieval village surrounded by a moat.
Being a private estate of the Kofuku-ji Temple in olden times, the town developed from a medieval village surrounded by a moat.
Being a private estate of the Kofuku-ji Temple in olden times, the town developed from a medieval village surrounded by a moat.

sen.j: 室町時代後期に、浄土真宗称念寺 (橿原市)を中心とする寺内町となり、東西南北の他、新町・今町の6町が成立した。
sen.e: In the late Muromachi period, the town evolved into a jinai-cho (a town within the precincts of a temple) around Shonen-ji Temple (Kashihara City) of Jodo Shinshu sect (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism), and six districts of East, West, South, North, Shinmachi, and Imamachi were established within the town.

In the late Muromachi period, the town evolved into a jinai-cho (a town within the precincts of a temple) around Shonen-ji Temple (Kashihara City) of Jodo Shinshu sect (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism), and six districts of East, West, South, North, Shinmachi, and Imamachi were established within the town.

In the late Muromachi period, the town evolved into a jinai-cho (a town within the precincts of a temple) around Shonen-ji Temple (Kashihara City) of Jodo Shinshu sect (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism), and six districts of East, West, South, North, Shinmachi, and Imamachi were established within the town.

sen.j: 石山合戦の際には、石山本願寺について織田信長に反抗、環濠や土塁、見通しを妨げる筋違いの道路等を築いて城塞都市となった。
sen.e: The town stood on the side of Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple in Ishiyama War to fight against Nobunaga ODA, and developed into a fortified city with a moat, earthworks, diagonally crossed roads to hinder the view, etc.

The town stood on the side of Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple in Ishiyama War to fight against Nobunaga ODA, and developed into a fortified city with a moat, earthworks, diagonally crossed roads to hinder the view, etc.

The town stood on the side of Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple in Ishiyama War to fight against Nobunaga ODA, and developed into a fortified city with a moat, earthworks, diagonally crossed roads to hinder the view, etc.

sen.j: 1575年、織田信長に降伏してからは大阪湾に面する堺市と並び称される自治都市として栄えた。
sen.e: After surrendering to Nobunaga ODA in 1575, the town flourished as an autonomous city, ranking with Sakai City which faces the Osaka Bay.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After surrendering to Nobunaga ODA in 1575, the town flourished as an autonomous city, ranking with Sakai City which faces Osaka Bay.
After surrendering to Nobunaga ODA in 1575, the town flourished as an autonomous city, ranking with Sakai City which faces Osaka Bay.

sen.j: 江戸時代には「大和の金は今井に七分」「金の虫干し玄関まで」と称されるまでになった。
sen.e: In the Edo period, the town was referred to by such sayings as "you could find 70 percent of all Yamato Province's money in Imai" and "they air the money even at the entrance."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the Edo period, the town was referred to by such sayings as "you could find 70 percent of all Yamato Province's money in Imai" and "they air the money even at the entrance."
In the Edo period, the town was referred to by such sayings as 'you could find 70 percent of all Yamato Province's money in Imai' and 'they air the money even at the entrance.'

sen.j: 江戸後期に重税により町は衰退に向かい、明治期には近隣に持ち上がった鉄道駅建設計画に反対したことから都市化を免れることができた（畝傍駅として開業）。
sen.e: In the late Edo period, the town started to decline due to the oppressive tax, and as it opposed the construction of a railway station proposed in its neighborhood in the Meiji period, it could avoid being urbanized (the station was opened as Unebi Station.)

In the late Edo period, the town started to decline due to the oppressive tax, and as it opposed the construction of a railway station proposed in its neighborhood in the Meiji period, it could avoid being urbanized (the station was opened as Unebi Station.)

In the late Edo period, the town started to decline due to the oppressive tax, and as it opposed the construction of a railway station proposed in its neighborhood in the Meiji period, it could avoid being urbanized (the station was opened as Unebi Station.)

sen.j: それゆえ現在も、町の大半が江戸時代の姿を残しており、大部分は実際に住居としても使用されている。
sen.e: Therefore, much of the town still remains as it was in the Edo period, and most of the houses are being used for actual dwelling.
Therefore, much of the town still remains as it was in the Edo period, and most of the houses are being used for actual dwelling.
Therefore, much of the town still remains as it was in the Edo period, and most of the houses are being used for actual dwelling.

sen.j: ただし中には廃屋同然に放置された建物も存在し、空家対策が必要である。
sen.e: Some buildings, however, were abandoned and left untouched, and measures for such empty houses are needed.
Some buildings, however, were abandoned and left untouched, and measures for such empty houses are needed.
Some buildings, however, were abandoned and left untouched, and measures for such empty houses are needed.

sen.j: 重要文化財9件12棟、県文化財3件11棟、市文化財4件4棟。
sen.e: 12 buildings of 9 places are registered as Important Cultural Properties, 11 buildings of 3 places and 4 buildings of 4 places are registered as prefectural and municipal cultural properties respectively.

12 buildings of 9 places are registered as Important Cultural Properties, 11 buildings of 3 places and 4 buildings of 4 places are registered as prefectural and municipal cultural properties respectively.

12 buildings of 9 places are registered as Important Cultural Properties, 11 buildings of 3 places and 4 buildings of 4 places are registered as prefectural and municipal cultural properties respectively.

sen.j: 重要伝統的建造物群保存地区に選定。
sen.e: The town is designated as a Preservation District for Groups of Historic Buildings.
The town is designated as a Preservation District for Groups of Historic Buildings.
The town is designated as a Preservation District for Groups of Historic Buildings.

tit.j: 重要伝統的建造物群保存地区データ
tit.e: Data for the Preservation District for Groups of Historic Buildings
Data for the Preservation District for Groups of Historic Buildings

sen.j: 地区名称：橿原市今井町
sen.e: District name: Imai town, Kashihara City
District name: Imai town, Kashihara City

sen.j: 種別：寺内町、自治都市
sen.e: Type: Jinai-cho, autonomous city
Type: Jinai-cho, autonomous city

sen.j: 選定年月日：平成5年12月8日
sen.e: Selection date: December 8, 1993
Selection date: December 8, 1993
Selection date: December 8, 1993

sen.j: 選定基準：伝統的建造物群が全体として意匠的に優秀なもの
sen.e: Selection criterion: A group of traditional buildings presenting excellent design as a whole
Selection criterion: A group of traditional buildings presenting excellent design as a whole

sen.j: 面積：17.4ha
sen.e: Area: 17.4 ha
Area: 17.4 ha
Area: 17.4 ha

sen.j: 今西家住宅（重要文化財） - 今西家は代々今井の惣年寄筆頭を務めた。
sen.e: Imanishi Residence (Important Cultural Property): Imanishi family served as the head of sodoshiyori (officers who worked under the town magistrate) of Imai town for generations.
Imanishi Residence (Important Cultural Property): Imanishi family served as the head of sodoshiyori (officers who worked under the town magistrate) of Imai town for generations.
Imanishi Residence (Important Cultural Property): Imanishi family served as the head of sodoshiyori (officers who worked under the town magistrate) of Imai town for generations.

sen.j: 今西家の先祖は、もと大和南部の豪族十市氏の一族だった。
sen.e: The Imanishi family originated from the Tochi clan, former local ruling family of southern part of Yamato Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Imanishi family originated from the Tochi clan, former local ruling family of southern Yamato Province.
The Imanishi family originated from the Tochi clan, former local ruling family of southern Yamato Province.

sen.j: 永禄9年（1566）に十市遠勝が筒井順慶に圧迫されて今井に亡命した後を追って川井助衛門尉正治が一族郎党をひきつれて当地に移住した。
sen.e: Tokatsu TOCHI defected to Imai to escape from suppression by Junkei TSUTSUI in 1566, followed by Sukeemonnojo Masaharu KAWAI moving to the town with his family and retainers.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「川井助衛門尉正治」は読み方が不明です。
sen.e: Tokatsu TOCHI defected to Imai to escape from suppression by Junkei TSUTSUI in 1566, followed by Sukeemonnojo Masaharu KAWAI moving to the town with his family and retainers.
Tokatsu TOCHI defected to Imai to escape from suppression by Junkei TSUTSUI in 1566, followed by Sukeemonnojo Masaharu KAWAI moving to the town with his family and retainers.

sen.j: 今井町の西口にあることから郡山城主徳川家康の孫松平忠明にすすめられて以後今西姓を名乗った。
sen.e: As the family settled in the western ("nishi" in Japanese) end of Imai town, it followed the advice of Tadaakira MATSUDAIRA, the lord of Koriyama Castle and Ieyasu TOKUGAWA's grandson, and used "Imanishi" as a family name.

As the family settled in the western ("nishi" in Japanese) end of Imai town, it followed the advice of Tadaakira MATSUDAIRA, the lord of Koriyama Castle and Ieyasu TOKUGAWA's grandson, and used "Imanishi" as a family name.

As the family settled in the western ("nishi" in Japanese) end of Imai Town, it followed the advice of Tadaakira MATSUDAIRA, the lord of Koriyama Castle and Ieyasu TOKUGAWA's grandson, and used "Imanishi" as a family name.

sen.j: 幕府から自治権を委ねられて、領主・代官の町方支配の一翼を担う。
sen.e: With the autonomy delegated by the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), the family contributed to ruling by a feudal lord and local governors over people in the town.
With the autonomy delegated by the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), the family contributed to ruling by a feudal lord and local governors over people in the town.
With the autonomy delegated by the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), the family contributed to ruling by a feudal lord and local governors over people in the town.

sen.j: 民家というより城郭を思わせる構造で、「八つ棟造り」と呼ばれる。
sen.e: The structure of the Imanishi Residence, which gives an impression of a castle wall rather than a private residence, is called "yatsumune" style (complicated roof style with multiple ridges and bargeboards).

The structure of the Imanishi Residence, which gives an impression of a castle wall rather than a private residence, is called "yatsumune" style (complicated roof style with multiple ridges and bargeboards).

The structure of the Imanishi Residence, which gives an impression of a castle rather than a private residence, is called 'yatsumune' style (complicated roof style with multiple ridges and bargeboards).
sen.cmt: wall 削除 （castle のみで良いと考えます。）" "→' '

sen.j: 内部には、お白洲があり裁判が行われ、罪人を閉じこめた部屋（いぶし牢）も残っている。
sen.e: Inside the house, there remains a court of law and a room for locking up criminals (ibusiro jail).
Inside the house, there remains a court of law and a room for locking up criminals (ibusiro jail).
Inside the house, there remains a court of law and a room for locking up criminals (ibushiro jail).

sen.j: 春秋それぞれ1か月間、一般公開している。
sen.e: The residence is open to the public for one month in spring and autumn.
The residence is open to the public for one month in spring and autumn.
The residence is open to the public for one month in spring and autumn.

sen.j: 慶安3年（1650）の建築で棟札も残っている。
sen.e: Built in 1650, it still has a ridge plaque.
Built in 1650, it still has a ridge plaque.
Built in 1650, it still has a ridge plaque.

sen.j: わが国の民家建築史上「一里塚」と言われるほどの貴重な建物である。
sen.e: This building is so valuable that it is referred to as a "milestone" in architectural history of Japanese private residence.
This building is so valuable that it is referred to as a "milestone" in architectural history of Japanese private residence.
This building is so valuable that it is referred to as a 'milestone' in architectural history of Japanese private residence.

sen.j: 昭和32年6月18日重文指定（附・棟札1枚）。
sen.e: It was designated as an Important Cultural Property on June 18, 1957 (together with a ridge plaque).
It was designated as an Important Cultural Property on June 18, 1957 (together with a ridge plaque).
It was designated as an Important Cultural Property on June 18, 1957 (together with a ridge plaque).

sen.j: 豊田家住宅（重要文化財） - 古くは材木商の牧村家の所有で「西の木屋」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Toyoda Residence (Important Cultural Property): Once owned by the Makimura family which ran a lumber business, it was called "Nishinokiya."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Toyoda Residence (Important Cultural Property): Once owned by the Makimura family which ran a lumber business, it was called "Nishinokiya."
Toyoda Residence (Important Cultural Property): Once owned by the Makimura family which ran a lumber business, it was called 'Nishinokiya.'

sen.j: 大名に貸し付けを行い藩の蔵元を務めていたほどの豪商だったが、明治維新後の廃藩置県により貸付金が凍結し今井を離れざるを得なかった。
sen.e: This merchant family was very wealthy, made loans to daimyo (Japanese territorial lord), and took charge of accounts in clan's warehouse, but after the Meiji Restoration, the family forced to leave Imai because Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures) caused the freezing of loans.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This merchant family was very wealthy, made loans to daimyo (Japanese territorial lord), and took charge of accounts in clan's warehouse, but after the Meiji Restoration, the family was forced to leave Imai because Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures) caused the freezing of loans.

This merchant family was very wealthy, made loans to daimyo (Japanese territorial lord), and took charge of accounts in clan's warehouse, but after the Meiji Restoration, the family was forced to leave Imai because Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures) caused the freezing of loans.

sen.j: なお大阪府堺市の大仙公園にある今井宗久ゆかりの茶室「黄梅庵」は、もと牧村家所有の茶室を移築したものである。
sen.e: "Obaian," a teahouse in Daisen-koen Park in Sakai City, Osaka Prefecture, is associated with Sokyu IMAI, and before being moved to the current location, it was owned by the Makimura family.
"Obaian," a teahouse in Daisen-koen Park in Sakai City, Osaka Prefecture, is associated with Sokyu IMAI, and before being moved to the current location, it was owned by the Makimura family.
Obaian, a teahouse in Daisen-koen Park in Sakai City, Osaka Prefecture, is associated with Sokyu IMAI, and before being moved to the current location, it was owned by the Makimura family.

sen.j: この茶室は秀吉公の吉野山花見に設けられ「宗久茶屋」と称せられた。
sen.e: The teahouse was built when Lord Hideyoshi visited Mt. Yoshino to enjoy cherry blossoms, and came to be called "Sokyu Teahouse."
The teahouse was built when Lord Hideyoshi visited Mt. Yoshino to enjoy cherry blossoms, and came to be called "Sokyu Teahouse."
The teahouse was built when Lord Hideyoshi visited Mt. Yoshino to enjoy cherry blossoms, and came to be called 'Sokyu Teahouse.'

sen.j: 住宅は寛文2年（1662）の建築で今井町では、今西家に次いで古い。
sen.e: The residence was constructed in 1662, making it the second oldest building in Imai town after the Imanishi Residence.
The residence was constructed in 1662, making it the second oldest building in Imai town after the Imanishi Residence.
The residence was constructed in 1662, making it the second oldest building in Imai Town after the Imanishi Residence.

sen.j: 昭和47年5月15日重文指定。
sen.e: It was designated as an Important Cultural Property on May 15, 1972.
It was designated as an Important Cultural Property on May 15, 1972.
It was designated as an Important Cultural Property on May 15, 1972.

sen.j: 称念寺 (橿原市) - 浄土真宗本願寺派の寺であり、御坊（今井山）である。
sen.e: Shonen-ji Temple (Kashihara City): The temple belongs to Jodo Shinshu Hongan-ji school and is a branch of Hongan-ji Temple (Imaisan).
Shonen-ji Temple (Kashihara City): The temple belongs to Jodo Shinshu Hongan-ji school and is a branch of Hongan-ji Temple (Imaisan).
Shonen-ji Temple (Kashihara City): The temple belongs to Jodo Shinshu sect Hongan-ji school and is a branch of Hongan-ji Temple (Imaisan).
sen.cmt: sect 追記「御坊」とは「僧侶または寺院の敬称」で、「～の寺で」と重複するのであえて入れておりません。

sen.j: 今井町は称念寺を中心に発展した寺内町であったが、織田信長に武装解除されてから後は、堺と共に自治都市として幕末まで栄えた。
sen.e: Imai town had developed as a jinai-cho around the Shonen-ji Temple, but after Nobunaga ODA disarmed the town, it enjoyed prosperity as an autonomous city, along with Sakai, until the end of the Edo period.

Imai town had developed as a jinai-cho around the Shonen-ji Temple, but after Nobunaga ODA disarmed the town, it enjoyed prosperity as an autonomous city, along with Sakai, until the end of the Edo period.

Imai Town had developed as a jinai-cho around the Shonen-ji Temple, but after Nobunaga ODA disarmed the town, it enjoyed prosperity as an autonomous city, along with Sakai, until the end of the Edo period.

sen.j: また明治10年（1877）2月10日～11日、明治天皇の「大和行幸」の際の今井行在所（あんざいしょ）であった。
sen.e: When the Emperor Meiji took "Yamato gyoko" (imperial trip to the Yamato Province), the temple was used as Imai anzaisho (provisional palace for Emperor's going out) on February 10 and 11, 1877.
When the Emperor Meiji took "Yamato gyoko" (imperial trip to the Yamato Province), the temple was used as Imai anzaisho (provisional palace for Emperor's going out) on February 10 and 11, 1877.
When the Emperor Meiji took 'Yamato gyoko' (imperial trip to the Yamato Province), the temple was used as Imai anzaisho (provisional palace for Emperor's going out) on February 10 and 11, 1877.

sen.j: 本堂は近世初頭に再建されたもので、平成14年5月23日国の重要文化財に指定された。
sen.e: Main hall of the temple was rebuilt in the early modern period and designated as a national Important Cultural Property on May 23, 2002.
The main hall of the temple was rebuilt in the early modern period and designated as a national Important Cultural Property on May 23, 2002.
The main hall of the temple was rebuilt in the early modern period and designated as a national Important Cultural Property on May 23, 2002.

sen.j: また、太鼓楼などが橿原市指定の文化財に指定されている。
sen.e: Taikoro (drum tower) and other buildings are also designated as cultural properties by Kashihara City.
Taikoro (drum tower) and other buildings are also designated as cultural properties by Kashihara City.
Taikoro (drum tower) and other buildings are also designated as cultural properties by Kashihara City.

sen.j: 中橋家住宅（重要文化財） - 屋号を「米彦」といい、米屋を営んでいた。
sen.e: Nakahashi Residence (Important Cultural Property): The Nakahashi family ran a rice store under the trade name of "Yonehiko."
Nakahashi Residence (Important Cultural Property): The Nakahashi family ran a rice store under the trade name of "Yonehiko."
Nakahashi Residence (Important Cultural Property): The Nakahashi family ran a rice store under the trade name of 'Yonehiko.'

sen.j: 建築年は分からないものの、寛廷元年（1748）の絵図に描かれていることから、当時すでに住居を構えていたことがわかる。
sen.e: It is not known when the residence was built, but given the fact that it appears on a pictorial map drawn in 1748, it had already been established around that time.
It is not known when the residence was built, but given the fact that it appears on a pictorial map drawn in 1748, it had already been established around that time.

sen.j: 宝暦11年（1761）には南町組頭を務めていた。
sen.e: The family served as a head of South District in 1761.
The family served as a head of South District in 1761.

sen.j: 昭和47年5月15日重文指定。
sen.e: The residence was designated as an Important Cultural Property on May 15, 1972.

sen.j: 上田家住宅（重要文化財） - 屋号を「壺屋」といい、今西家・尾崎家と並び惣年寄を勤めていた。
sen.e: Ueda Residence (Important Cultural Property): The Ueda family traded under the name of "Tsuboya," and worked as sodoshiyori along with the Imanishi and Ozaki families.
Ueda Residence (Important Cultural Property): The Ueda family traded under the name of "Tsuboya," and worked as sodoshiyori along with the Imanishi and Ozaki families.

sen.j: 惣年寄の旗が残っている。
sen.e: There remains a flag of sodoshiyori.
There remains a flag of sodoshiyori.

sen.j: 延享元年（1744）の祈祷札がありこの頃の建築とみられる。
sen.e: Ofuda talisman dated 1744 was found, which shows the residence was constructed around that time.
An ofuda talisman dated 1744 was found, which shows the residence was constructed around that time.

sen.j: 入母屋造りで、大壁造の妻をみせた外観は重厚な感じを与えている。
sen.e: The residence is built in the irimoya style (half-hipped roof style), and okabe style (a style in which structural members are hidden inside a wall) and an exposed gable add a heavy feel to its appearance.

sen.j: 入口が西に構えてるのは珍しい。
sen.e: The entrance is on the western side, which is uncommon.

sen.j: 音村家住宅（重要文化財） - 屋号を「細九」といい、かつては金物問屋を営んでいた。
sen.e: Otomura Residence (Important Cultural Property): The Otomura family once acted as a hardware wholesale merchant under the trade name of "Hosoku."

sen.j: 旧米谷家（こめたにけ）住宅（重要文化財） -屋号を「米忠」といい、代々金具商、肥料商を営んでいた。
sen.e: Former Kometani Residence (Important Cultural Property): The Kometani family was fittings and fertilizer merchant for generations, with the trade name of "Yonetada."
Former Kometani Residence (Important Cultural Property): The Kometani family was fittings and fertilizer merchant for generations, with the trade name of "Yonetada."

sen.j: 農家風の民家で、18世紀中頃の建築と推定される。
sen.e: This private residence is built in a farmhouse style, and is estimated to date back to the mid 18th century.
This private residence is built in a farmhouse style, and is estimated to date back to the mid 18th century.
This private residence is built in a farmhouse style, and is estimated to date back to the mid 18th century.

sen.j: 内部は無料で一般公開されている。
sen.e: The inside of the residence is open to the public for free.
The inside of the residence is open to the public for free.

sen.j: 昭和47年5月15日重文指定。
sen.e: It was designated as an Important Cultural Property on May 15, 1972.
It was designated as an Important Cultural Property on May 15, 1972.
It was designated as an Important Cultural Property on May 15, 1972.

sen.j: 河合家住宅（重要文化財） - 屋号を「上品寺屋」といい、寛永年間に上品寺村（橿原市上品寺町）から移住した。
sen.e: Kawai Residence (Important Cultural Property): The Kawai family bore the trade name "Jobonjiya" and moved from Jobonji village (Jobonji-cho, Kashihara City) in the Kanei era.
Kawai Residence (Important Cultural Property): The Kawai family bore the trade name "Jobonjiya" and moved from Jobonji village (Jobonji-cho, Kashihara City) in the Kanei era.

sen.j: 家蔵文書によると明和9年（1772）には既に酒を造っており、今なお酒造業を営んでいる。
sen.e: Documents owned by the family suggest that the family had already been brewing sake in 1772, and it is still engaged in sake brewing business.
Documents owned by the family suggest that the family had already been brewing sake in 1772, and it is still engaged in sake brewing business.
Documents owned by the family suggest that the family had already been brewing sake in 1772, and it is still engaged in sake brewing business.

sen.j: 18世紀後半の建築。
sen.e: The residence was built in the late 18th century.
The residence was built in the late 18th century.
The residence was built in the late 18th century.

sen.j: 昭和51年5月20日重文指定。
sen.e: It was designated as an Important Cultural Property on May 20, 1976.
It was designated as an Important Cultural Property on May 20, 1976.
It was designated as an Important Cultural Property on May 20, 1976.

sen.j: 高木家住宅（重要文化財） - 屋号を「大東の四条屋」といい、酒造業を営んでいた。
sen.e: Takagi Residence (Important Cultural Property): The Takagi family was involved in sake brewing business under the trade name of "Daito no Shijoya."
sen.cmt: 「大東の四条屋」は読み方が不明です。
sen.e: Takagi Residence (Important Cultural Property): The Takagi family was involved in sake brewing business under the trade name of "Daito no Shijoya."
Takagi Residence (Important Cultural Property): The Takagi family was involved in sake brewing business under the trade name of 'Daito no Shijoya.'

sen.j: 切妻造本瓦葺きの２階建てで、幕末上層民家の特徴が残る。
sen.e: This two-story house is built in kirizuma (an architectural style with a gabled roof) and hongawarabuki (a style of tile roofing in which round and square tiles are laid down alternately) styles, which displays the characteristics of a private residence of people in the upper class in the end of the Edo period.

sen.j: 江戸時代末期(文政～天保頃) の建物。
sen.e: The residence was built in the end of the Edo period (Bunsei to Tenpo eras).

sen.j: 昭和47年5月15日重文指定。
sen.e: It was designated as an Important Cultural Property on May 15, 1972.

sen.j: 吉村家（県指定文化財）－旧は上田家で、屋号を「壺八」といい、肥料商を営んでいた。
sen.e: Yoshimura Residence (prefectural cultural property): This residence was formerly owned by the Ueda family which acted as a fertilizer merchant under the trade name of "Tsuboya."
sen.cmt: 「壺八」は正しくは「壺屋」だと思われます。

sen.j: 主家は文化二年（1805）の再建とみられるが、他の建物は、主家より約50年程さかのぼるとみられている。
sen.e: Main building is believed to have been rebuilt in 1805, and other buildings are thought to be about 50 years older than the main building.
The main building is believed to have been rebuilt in 1805, and other buildings are thought to be about 50 years older than the main building.

sen.j: 山尾家（県指定文化財）-山尾家は、十市郡新堂村より移住したので「新堂屋」の屋号で、幕末には、町年寄を務めた。
sen.e: Yamao Residence (prefectural cultural property): The Yamao family moved from Shindo village, Toichi County, thus bearing the trade name "Shindoya," and served as machi-doshiyori (ward head) in the end of the Edo period.

sen.j: 今井まちなみ交流センター「華甍（はないらか）」 （県指定文化財） - 今井町に関する資料を展示する。
sen.e: Imai Machinami Exchange Center "Hanairaka" (prefectural cultural property): Materials on Imai town are exhibited.

sen.j: 建物は明治36年の建築で旧高市郡教育博物館であった。

sen.j: 今井まちや館 - 本町筋の中央部にある18世紀初期の町家。
sen.e: Imai Machiyakan: It is machiya (a traditional townhouse) building built in the early 18th century around the middle of Honmachi-suji Street.

sen.j: 旧常福寺観音堂（市指定文化財）- 慶長18年（1613）建立。

sen.j: 橿原市今井町3丁目162 春日神社内にある。
sen.e: It is within the precincts of Kasuga-jinja Shrine at 162, 3-chome, Imai-cho, Kashihara City.

sen.j: 春日神社-堺の有力商人から寄贈された手水鉢（ちょうずばち）が今も残る。
sen.e: Kasuga-jinja Shrine: There still remains chozubachi (a water basin used to rinse the hands or as a decorative element in gardens) donated by a powerful merchant in Sakai.

sen.j: 江戸時代からの秋のだんじり祭りは、今もなお勇壮に続いている。
sen.e: Danjiri (decorative portable shrine) festival which dates back to the Edo period is still held livelily in autumn today.

sen.j: 今井都市緑化-今井町の西南隅で、一部に環濠が残る。
sen.e: Imai urban greening: It refers to the southwestern corner of Imai town, in part of which the moat is still left.
sen.cmt: 「今井都市緑化」は「今井都市緑地」のことだと思われますが、訳は原文どおりとしています。

sen.j: 今井児童公園-織田信長公本陣跡があったが第二次大戦の空襲による火事を回避するため取り壊したとの事。
sen.e: Imai Children's Park: It is said that remains of headquarters of Lord Nobunaga ODA's army were left in this place but they were removed to keep them from being burned in air raids during World War II.
